all_paragraphs: By Dirk Knemeyer and Jonathan Follett

Could the future of advertising make our lives better? Most people hate advertising: the awful messages in podcasts trying to get you to buy something you’re not interested in, the display ads on seemingly every Web site in existence, and the pop-up videos that explode on your screen and headphones, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing. It’s a kind of commercially acceptable torture, really.

There is no global opt-out. Participating in public digital spaces includes an implicit social contract to absorb this cacophony of noise. While your brain has become adept at shoving these intrusions into the background, they are still there — adding a patina of irritation over what you are otherwise trying to accomplish or enjoy.

Yet, it is the advertising that brings you the very platforms you’re using. The reality is that the creators need to be paid for the things that they make. The Internet, for many reasons, has cultivated a culture where people want things for free. And advertising has sidled in to serve as the payment surrogate. We may find it evil, but it’s a necessary one. Without it, the Internet would be but a shell of what it is today, or perhaps would be employing alternate monetization strategies that are even more odious.

Andy Mauro, co-founder and CEO of Automat, envisions a future where marketing and advertising provide value-added services for the consumer — as opposed to following the long tradition of disrupting and degrading our experiences. Mauro has been working in speech recognition for almost 20 years, and his company, Automat, creates conversational AI for brands.

“I sometimes say to people, ‘I spent the first half of my career working on things that people hate — those over-the-phone speech [recognition] systems, and the second half of my career working on things that nobody used — which is the mobile voice assistants, like Siri,” says Mauro. “In a very real way we’re still seeking the elusive killer use case in conversational AI.”

Conversational AI is the all-encompassing moniker for speech recognition, smart speakers, and chatbots — the wide range of language-based conversational technology. “I think it’s actually quite useful to have a single term,” says Mauro. “Because the underlying tech is almost identical from a natural language understanding perspective. The ability to understand spoken or typed free form text, and the technology that goes into building a dialogue, a back and forth conversation — it’s almost exactly the same between speech and text based inputs.”

One of the technologies on which Mauro and the team at Automat are working are conversational display ads. “I think a really good place to focus attention, if you’re trying to build something meaningful, is something that everyone does and no one likes,” says Mauro. “I don’t think many consumers would say that they like display ads. I would say most brands who spend lots of money on them would also probably say, ‘I’m not sure that I love them either.’ There’s issues around, did anybody see them? Is the thing that saw them a real person, or was it some sort of automated system that’s juicing the numbers? And ultimately, did I get any value from this ad?”

A conversational display ad tries to provide something better for consumers. “For example, I’m reading a car blog. I’m a car enthusiast and I’m thinking about buying a car, and I see an ad. Today that ad, at best, is going to give me some financing information and the picture of the car. And if I click on it, it’s going to bring me to the manufacturer’s Web site or a dealership. It’s taking me away from the content I was reading,” says Mauro. “With a conversational display ad, I can click into that ad, not leave the content page … and I can chat with a virtual sales advisor who could tell me some things about the car, answer my questions, maybe even schedule me a test drive. So, that’s a better consumer experience. And really, really importantly, in this world of data privacy and security, and all the things that are happening with Google and Facebook … this is pretty transparent and very opt-in from a consumer perspective. You know that you’re chatting with a brand, and when you are providing information about what you might be looking for. It’s much more transparent than making a search, or liking something on Facebook, which you have no idea that you’re opting into a commercial transaction or an advertising transaction.” That sounds like a huge upgrade. Whereas, today, ads are things you subconsciously block out even before you realize they are there, the type of functionality Mauro describes is more assistive. It’s an online experience in sync with users’ needs and desires, while also offering corporate interests compensation and incentive.

There’s no question that e-commerce is ripe for innovation. “For those of us who’ve been around for a while, being able to shop in your pajamas at 3:00 AM was an amazing experience. It compressed both time and space in a way that the best and most successful innovations often do,” says Mauro. “But nobody’s really thought about [that experience] a whole lot in the last 20 years. I mean, e-commerce is still mostly just grids of product images, whether you’re buying batteries, or you’re buying a $5,000 handbag, or you’re buying a car.”

“We discovered that there’s all kinds of categories of e-commerce where graceful service can be both a much better consumer experience, and drive much better business results by basically just chatting with your customers,” says Mauro. “We’re usually talking about a web or mobile experience that’s … a text based chat. And we’ve seen just really amazing results from an engagement perspective, from a customer satisfaction perspective.”

The Automat team is also working on connecting the consumer experience across channels via conversational AI. For many consumers, the cross-channel experience for a company — from the Web site to the app to the brick-and-mortar store — can seem disconnected and highly variant. “We think this idea of using conversational experiences tied to brand personalities could be a good way to deliver a connected experience,” says Mauro. “I can have a unified conversation with the same person — in this case a virtual avatar — and get what I need throughout the consumer journey.” From the brand’s perspective, having consistency across channels is important. Part of brand strategy is identifying that brand’s personality. Voice enables that strategic vision to manifest in a virtual avatar. And, since chatbot and voice technology is so easily nestled into any digital interface, it can become seemingly ubiquitous. “That’s a pretty connected experience,” says Mauro. “Even if you chatted on the Web to learn about the product, and maybe you chatted on mobile to get the order status, and maybe you had a usage question and you actually talked to your smart speaker.”

Automat spoke to hundreds of individual consumers who enjoyed having a conversation on a brand or retailer Web site. “People felt like they got information they couldn’t otherwise find on the Web site,” says Mauro. “Now, in reality, the Web site almost always had that product information somewhere, but it was … in a place where they had to do a lot of reading to get at it. And so, they felt like they got information they couldn’t otherwise get.”

What this all boils down to is task completion. Rather than navigating hopelessly around a site, rather than chatting with a human who is juggling you with many other customers, the chatbot — if done well — can just pluck the pertinent information from the database and quickly give it to you. As a consequence, you’ll feel like it went more quickly and actually spend more time engaged with the company. “A lot of people think that guided product recommendation like this is about product discovery, finding the right product. And what we learned is, while that’s of course true, what it’s really about is product confidence. So, people were finding products okay, but what they really needed was someone, or in this case, something, to reinforce and tell them why this was in fact the right product for them.

Of course, while conversational AI can create some big wins, it is not foolproof. “In language, humans are far, far, far better than machines are,” says Mauro. “I think we’re a ways off from a fundamental change.” There’s usually not a single intent, or one single underlying message, in human communication. Language is more complex than that, but right now, NLP technology has its limits. “The underlying technical infrastructure is forcing us down a path where every sentence needs to meet in one thing.” says Mauro. “And that’s not really how language works.” The next breakthrough in natural language processing may require continuous understanding — where a machine can interpret the meaning, not just of what a person is saying at the moment, but also how that meaning evolves as the person continues to speak. “There’s real, legitimate, philosophical and technical debate about is language tantamount to the AGI or artificial general intelligence problem,” says Mauro. “If you solve language, have you made computers as smart as humans? And are those two things very related?”

Mauro has some inspiring thoughts about how these technologies might change the landscape of future work. “What automated capabilities might we get that we haven’t anticipated, that don’t automate an existing job, but in fact do something that hasn’t been before? Where can I get help that I otherwise don’t have in any way, shape or form? I think that’s a much more creative, hopeful, exciting way to look at it. I would just really challenge everyone to get out of the idea of somebody has job X, let’s make an AI do it. And let’s think about providing new forms of employment that only AIs can [help enable],” says Mauro. If conversational AI can help enable a better consumer experience, maybe new forms of marketing work are on their way, too.

Creative Next is a podcast exploring the impact of AI-driven automation on the lives of creative workers, people like writers, researchers, artists, designers, engineers, and entrepreneurs. This article accompanies Season 2, Episode 9 — Frontiers of Conversational Marketing.
